newsitem.title: GERMANY: German rye and barley harvests make swift progress.
newsitem.headline: German rye and barley harvests make swift progress.

text.p: Barley and rye harvests across Germany have made good progress and will be completed over the next fortnight when wheat reaches maturity, farm sources said.
Barley prices were easing under harvest pressure and a lack of demand so most farmers were planning to store the grain to await market developments in the early autumn, they said.
Northern states reported roughly three quarters of barley had been cut, with some wheat and triticale also harvested.
Barley yields in the north were in a broad range between 5.5 and 8.00 tonnes per hectare (tph) versus the pan-German 1996 average of 5.61 tph.
Farmers in Schleswig-Holstein, in northern Germany, reported barley yield spikes of 8.00-9.00 tph on heavy soils.

Farmers in North Rhine-Westphalia, Rhineland-Palatinate and Hesse reported similar barley results, although rainfall in these regions in the middle of Germany had been more frequent and excessive, boosting moisture levels.

Spring barley with malting properties had been harvested with 10-11 percent protein in Saar state, 11.5 percent in the adjacent Rhineland, 9-11 percent in Baden-Wuerttenberg and 9-11.5 percent in Baden.
But Bavaria said malting qualities would be rare this year.
Farmers in other southern states had nearly completed the barley harvest and were reporting medium to good yields.
In eastern Germany, Thuringia state had only completed 50 percent of the barley harvest with yields in a 4.00-8.00 tph range and Saxony was also reporting a wide range of 5.6-10.0 tph.
Domestic wheat prices were slow to emerge ahead of the harvest because buyers and sellers could not agree on levels as early quality indications were too varied.
Initially low rye falling numbers, an indicator of baking qualities, depressed prices.
Falling numbers below 100/120 disqualify rye for flour use.
In Saxony and Thuringia, they varied between 80 and 180 and in North Rhine-Westphalia, they were between 120 and 160.
